270. Edwards, Maude (Mrs. John Russell)
What did early Canadian pioneers eat?
A QUESTIONNAIRE

Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Name: Mrs. Maude Edwards
Address: 270 Edwards, Maude (Mrs. John Russell)
Birthplace: England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
   What year did you start housekeeping in eastern Canada? 1913
   Where did you set up housekeeping? Edmonton
   Where had you been living before that? England
   For how many people did you prepare meals? 5
   How far was it to your nearest store? 2 miles
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Twice a week
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Sugar, oats, tea, butter, baking powder.

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) **Well, for drinking, slough for cooking.**

How far was this water from your home? **2 miles.**

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) **Barrel or maybe cart.**

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

**7 years after coming found water in a well, close to house, 70 ft. deep.**
There did not exist water for drinking and for cooking (well, river, slooch, drount). If ever was this water for your house? How was it brought to the honey (pail, barrel, tank) before all arrangements? First started homestead living, states possible. Next came land which have to plant first. Aridness, drought, rainfall, water in a well, close to house, 70 feet deep.

16. **TRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS**

Mention any changes which you recall in the trappings and containers received with the food you purchased (five dates where possible).

Cotton bags, wooden pails for jam, tin pails for hard, paper bags, wooden boxes for dried fruits & raisins, tea in lead wrapper.

Luncheon: stewed rabbit & dumplings with syrup, potatoes & tea.
Supper: soup, bread & butter, jam & tea.
